global_flags.description: This option shows the version number of the xauth executable.
This  option indicates that xauth should attempt to break any authority file locks before proceeding.  Use this option only to clean up stale locks.
option specifies the name of the authority file to use.  By default, xauth will use the file specified by the XAUTHORITY envi‐ ronment variable or .Xauthority in the user's home directory.

This option indicates that xauth should ignore any authority file locks.  Normally, xauth will refuse to read or edit any  authority files that have been locked by other programs (usually xdm or another xauth).
This option indicates that xauth should not attempt to resolve any hostnames, but should simply always print  the  host  address  as stored in the authority file.

This option indicates that xauth should operate quietly and not print unsolicited status messages.  This is the default if an  xauth command is given on the command line or if the standard output is not directed to a terminal.

This  option  indicates  that  xauth should operate verbosely and print status messages indicating the results of various operations (e.g., how many records have been read in or written out).  This is the default if xauth is reading commands from its standard input and its standard output is directed to a terminal.

subcommands.name: Authorization
subcommands.description: entries  for  each of the specified displays are written to the indicated file.  If the nextract command is used, the entries are written in a numeric format suitable for non-binary transmission (such as secure electronic mail).   The  extracted  en‐ tries  can be read back in using the merge and nmerge commands.  If the filename consists of just a single dash, the entries will be written to the standard output.

subcommands.name: The
subcommands.description: data  option specifies data that the server should use to generate the authorization.  Note that this is not the same data that gets written to the authorization file.  The interpretation of this data depends on the authorization protocol.  The hexdata  is  in the same format as the hexkey described in the add command.  The default is to send no data.

subcommands.name: This
subcommands.description: command  is  similar to add.  The main difference is that instead of requiring the user to supply the key data, it connects to the server specified in displayname and uses the SECURITY extension in order to get the key data to store in the authorization file. If the server cannot be contacted or if it does not support the SECURITY extension, the command fails.  Otherwise, an  authorization entry  for  the indicated display using the given protocol is added to the authorization file.  A protocol name consisting of just a single period is treated as an abbreviation for MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1.

subcommands.name: exit
subcommands.description: If  any  modifications  have  been  made,  the authority file is written out (if allowed), and the program exits.  An end of file is treated as an implicit exit command.

subcommands.name: trusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are trusted

subcommands.name: untrusted
subcommands.description: clients using this entry are untrusted

subcommands.name: info
subcommands.description: Information describing the authorization file, whether or not any changes have been made, and from where xauth  commands  are  being read is printed on the standard output.

subcommands.name: quit
subcommands.description: The program exits, ignoring any modifications.  This may also be accomplished by pressing the interrupt character.

subcommands.name: version
subcommands.description: show version number of xauth ? list available commands
